qas.question: How is the Eritrean highway system named?
What are the three levels of road classification in Eritrea?
What are T roads, the lowest level that typically serves local interests?

answers.text: improved earth roads which are occasionally paved

qas.question: What are S roads, the mid-level that connects district capitals to regional capitals?
What are P roads, those that carry traffic between all major towns in Eritrea?

context: The Eritrean highway system is named <a0_0>according to the road classification<a0_0/>. The three levels of classification are: <a1_0>primary (P), secondary (S), and tertiary (T)<a1_0/>. The lowest level road is tertiary and serves local interests. Typically they are <a2_0>improved earth roads which are occasionally paved<a2_0/>. During the wet seasons these roads typically become impassable. The next higher level road is a secondary road and typically is a <a3_0>single-layered asphalt road<a3_0/> that connects district capitals together and those to the regional capitals. Roads that are considered primary roads are those that are <a4_0>fully asphalted (throughout their entire length)<a4_0/> and in general they carry traffic between all the major towns in Eritrea.
